 Well from our view, or my view anyway, the Yankees have always been the team that was the "Holier Than Thou" in baseball (I don't mean that religiously) That's why I enjoied it in 2001 when the Yanks lost the world series to Arizona, a team that at that time was still new by no more than a couple of years. Infact, I was to the point last year where if the Yankees went to the World Series, I just wan't going to root for the American League any more, ever. I would root for the National League. Thankfully, Boston came up and did the unthinkable. Now, in other countries, the Yankees are probibly the "ideal" of American Baseball. That is probibly why when America goes to another country not in North America, they are called "a Yankee" or so I've heard. The way I see it, in America, you either hate the Yankees or you love them. And the ones who love them the most are in New York.
 But that's just my take on it.
Right now the BoSox seem to be slipping with Cleveland on a hot streak now. Hey, I'll take the Indians. Buffalo is Cleveland's AAA team.

 I suppose from a "non partisan" point of view, British followers of MLB think that the New York Yankees are la crème de la crème (because they can afford to hire the best players etc.) They have created a sort of mystique with their great record in the World Series, and I hope they qualify again next month.
 
 I see that Alex Rodriguez has just matched Joltin' Joe's record in smashing homers at Yankee Stadium: another thing about baseball - it's a heaven for statistics nuts.

 I suppose by "they" you mean Steinbrunner? Anyway, if he had to operate with the kind of money other teams have they could easily be an under-.500 team. Take a look at how many people have stayed throughout the years. They got Giambi and make Oakland look good. They got Womack from AZ and now he's gone. They have made a few good decisions such as Scheffield and A-Rod. Matsui they actually got through their farm organization (I think) and Posada's been there forever. Other than that, they keep pumping dollar after dollar into the system and rarely actually getting a quality player. Last year, the Cards were spending over $100 million less and had a better winning percentage. I would guess the same is true this year. The angels have a decent team but a low payroll. Steinbrunner throws money this way and that and expects to win series', and it worked for a while, but they haven't won in a while and I hope they never do in the near future. They always are contenders, but when it comes down to the wire, they can't come through. 
 
 I see a Red Sox-Cards rematch series. Boston has an amazing pitching staff that pretty much won it last year. They've got Schilling, Wells, Clement, and then come back with Wakefield, such a difference from the other 3 with his knuckleballs. Then they have the offense behind Ortiz, Manny, Varitek, Renteria, Damon, Nixon, wow.
 
 But the Cards have Carpenter, Mulder, Morris, Marquis, Mulder, Suppan. All of these pitchers are amazing. Then they have Pujols, Eckstein (good lead-off hitter), Walker, Edmonds, Sanders. And when Isringhausen comes out, he pretty much always shuts it down for the last inning.
 
 Of course it will be difficult for any team to beat the trio of Pettite-Oswalt-Clemens.

 That call against the Angels was awful because he definately made the out call. BUT the catcher admitted that he didn't look to see if it was an out, he just rolled it out. This was a huge mental error on his part. Catchers are trained to no matter what if there is any doubt, just tag the guy. How many times do you see one that they catch, are called out, but they still tag just to be safe? He should have tagged just to be sure and then flipped it to the mound. Instead he and the Angels got screwed.

 I am a Cubs fan, but I'll cheer for the White Sox in the World Series.
 
 That said, you are right about that call. The home plate ump had been calling strikeouts all night EXACTLY as he did on the controversial call. But, the catcher should have reached and tagged the hitter automatically -- he knew if it was a foul tip and he knew it was close to (or bounced up from) the dirt when he gloved it.
